Dear Sir/Madam,
This is just placeholder text. Don’t be alarmed, this is just here to fill up space since your finalized copy isn’t ready yet. Once we have your content finalized, we’ll replace this placeholder text with your real content.
Sometimes it’s nice to put in text just to get an idea of how text will fill in a space on your website.
Traditionally our industry has used Rochester and Strood, which is placeholder text written in Latin. Unfortunately, not everyone is familiar with Rochester and Strood and that can lead to confusion. I can’t tell you how many times clients have asked me why their website is in another language!
There are other placeholder text alternatives like Hipster and Strood, Zombie and Strood, Bacon and Strood, and many more. While often hilarious, these placeholder passages can also lead to much of the same confusion.

There is so much potential in our local communities. I am working hard to unlock this and make sure our interests are represented in Westminster.
Accessibility Tools

Lauren visited Moot Brewery in Halling last week to discuss the challenges and opportunities facing the microbrewery sector and how she could support them as the local MP.
The microbrewery, run by Patrick and his team, opened 18 months ago. It is a great local start up success story, serving cask and keg beers from an onsite taproom as well as Kentish wines, cider, and coffee. Local micropubs in the constituency, such as the Dead Pigeon and Wolfe and Castle, regularly host their beers, offering Medway drinkers a taste of Medway in their local.
Barry Watts from the Society of Independent Brewers (SIBA) also joined the visit. He welcomed announcements in the recent Budget which increased Draught Relief from 9.2% to 13.9% from 1 February, as well as an increase in the differential in the Small Producer Relief which specifically assists small breweries. They discussed what the new government’s overhaul of business rates should look like to support the industry, as well as securing Moot a spot as a guest beer at the Houses of Parliament bar in the near future.

Last week Lauren voted for Labour’s Water (Special Measures) Bill which will reduce sewage spills and hold water companies accountable with tough penalties for breaking the law.
After years of unacceptable number of sewage overspills spoiling our natural environments and making our rivers and seas unsafe to swim in the government has acted.
As well as penalties for law breaking bosses, there will be new powers to ban bonuses, bigger fines for companies polluting our waterways and more investment into the system which protects the environment and delivers better services to consumers.
Commenting on the issue Lauren said ‘It is critical that the government grapples with the issue of unacceptable sewage spills which spoil our environment and can even make a trip to the seaside a health hazard. Enough is enough and I am pleased that these measures will secure improvements in the quality of water in the River Medway and Thames Estuary that so many local people enjoy and make our area so unique’.
Lauren also spoke recently to representatives from the campaigning charity 38 degrees to pledge her support for ending sewage spills and improving water quality.

I am proud to have been elected as your Member of Parliament for Rochester and Strood in July 2024. There is so much potential in our local communities, and I am working hard to unlock this and make sure our interests are represented in Westminster.
I moved to Rochester with my family in 2016 and am delighted to represent the diverse community that I call home.
Prior to being elected as the MP for Rochester and Strood in July 2024, I was the Cabinet Member responsible for Economic and Social Regeneration and Inward Investment on Medway Council from May 2023, and a Rochester East ward councillor from December 2021.
In my Medway Council Cabinet role, I sat on a number of regional external bodies focused on economic growth and skills, such as the South East Local Enterprise Partnership, the Kent and Medway Economic Partnership, the Kent and Medway Employment Taskforce, and the Kent and Medway Business Fund.
My professional background is as a financial regulator at the Bank of England, where I made sure that financial companies followed the rules put in place after the 2008 Financial Crisis. Prior to that, I worked as the lead postal researcher at the Communication Workers Union, focused on pay negotiations with Royal Mail and the Post Office. I also worked for a number of Labour MPs in Parliament.
I have over a decade of experience as an elected trade union representative.
I was born in Altona in Australia and came to the UK in 2005 to undertake a Master’s degree at the London School of Economics and Political Science.

- The government is rolling out free breakfast clubs to save working families up to £450 and set children up to start the day ready to learn.
- First 750 schools to offer clubs from April, delivering on government’s Plan for Change.
Families and children in Rochester and Strood will soon benefit from free, daily breakfast clubs as the government confirms the first 750 schools to offer the scheme, including St Helen’s Church of England Primary School in Cliffe, putting up to £450 a year back in local parents’ pockets.
From April, the school will be included in the early adopter phase set to inform Labour’s landmark national roll out which will give all pupils access to the scheme.
This delivers on promises made to working parents in Labour’s manifesto for all primary aged children to be able to access a free breakfast and at least 30 minutes of free childcare, every day, helping to support parents getting into work. Universal free breakfast clubs are central to Labour’s Plan for Change, removing barriers to opportunity by making sure every child starts the school day ready to learn.
Lauren Edwards MP for Rochester and Strood, said:
“I am absolutely delighted that St Helen’s CEP in Cliffe has been selected as one of the first schools to benefit from free breakfast clubs. I hope to visit the school later in the year to see the positive benefits the scheme has provided for children’s learning”.
“My government is determined to break down the barriers to children achieving their full potential. We know that hungry children struggle to learn, so the government’s free breakfast clubs will help all children to get the most out of their education.”

Please consult their website first for further information.

People who have problems with any aspect of the service they receive from the Department for Work and Pensions (DWP) or an organisation providing services on its behalf can complain, whether or not a claim for benefit has been made. The DWP’s Customer Charter sets out the standards of service the public can expect from it.
Before contacting your MP you should first try and resolve any issue with the DWP. Your MP will try and support you where you have exhausted the challenge/complaint process.

This week Lauren Edwards, MP for Rochester and Strood, joined a group of Labour MPs from Kent and Sussex to meet with the Rail Minister Lord Hendy to put pressure on the government to help bring international rail services back to Kent.
Eurostar suspended their services from Ashford and Ebbsfleet international stations during the COVID19 pandemic, and, despite calls from MPs to reopen services in Kent, are still yet to confirm when services will resume.
There is the prospect of other operators running an international rail service that stops in Kent, and the MPs were pleased to hear that officials at the Department for Transport are working hard to identify potential operators and remove any barriers. The MPs will meet with other interested parties, including Virgin and Evolyn in the coming weeks to discuss this further.
The meeting with the Rail Minister followed an opportunity Lauren and other MPs had to speak with the Eurostar Chief Executive in Parliament last week.
Commenting on the productive discussions with the Minister, Lauren said:
“Today’s meeting was encouraging, with the Rail Minister fully appreciating the economic boost our region would get from restoring international rail services from Kent stations.
It cost UK taxpayers £3bn to develop the Eurostar service and yet we have facilities at Ashford and Ebbsfleet stations that are being wasted, forcing Kent passengers to travel to London unnecessarily and at great cost.
The previous Conservative government sold the UK’s 40% stake in Eurostar back in 2015 for only £757m so the current government lacks the leverage it once had to influence the provision of Eurostar services.
I’m delighted the new Labour government is listening to me and the people of Medway and Kent by already working hard to see how we can open the international rail lines up to competitors and restore services in Kent.
There is a big appetite amongst residents in Rochester and Strood to bring international rail back to Kent and I’ll continue to work hard with other Labour MPs in our region to make this happen.”

Lauren was the guest of the Mortimer Society in November 2024 to formally open their new lift at Frindsbury House, Wainscott.
These new facilities provide enhanced access in their two-storey building making it easier to accommodate residents and visitors with mobility issues.
As well as a formal opening ceremony, Lauren took the opportunity to learn more about the important community-based care provided for residents with Huntington’s disease and other neurological conditions.
She later spoke about the care home during the Budget debate in the House of Commons. During the debate, she called for a more integrated health and social care system and said she hoped that future Budgets would allow charitable care homes such as Frindsbury House to be eligible for the same exemptions given to the NHS.
Lauren commented:
“It was a pleasure to be asked to formally open the new lift at Frindsbury House and to have the opportunity to meet with staff, residents and volunteers from the Mortimer Society.
“This facility is a crucial part of the residential care landscape in Rochester and Strood providing important community-based care to residents. I greatly appreciated the opportunity to learn more about how they help people with neurological conditions such as Huntington’s disease.
“I was also pleased to highlight their fantastic work during the Budget debate in the House of Commons, where I also called for a more integrated health and social care systems and for charitable care homes to be eligible for the same exemptions as the NHS in future Budgets.”

Lauren recently spoke in Parliament, urging the Prime Minister to enhance funding for further and adult education, particularly in crucial sectors like construction. She was incredibly pleased to hear the government later announce plans to inject over £600 million into technical skills, aiming to train up to 60,000 new engineers, bricklayers, electricians, and carpenters by 2029.
This significant investment will also establish ten new technical colleges, providing teachers with the latest resources and equipment. This initiative is designed to prepare a generation capable of building 1.5 million houses over the next five years and transitioning to a green economy.
By increasing the supply of homes, the plan aims to make affordable housing a reality while redeveloping brownfield land to rejuvenate communities. This approach not only supports economic growth but also revitalizes underused sites, ensuring towns evolve into more inclusive, sustainable, and vibrant places to live.
In Rochester and Strood, local colleges are already doing amazing work for young people and boosting skills not just in construction but in a wide range of sectors. This investment will enable them to progress even further. MidKent College, for instance, has been granted over £1.7 million in capital spending as part of a Department for Education scheme to help colleges prepare for the future.
Both the new funding for construction skills and for college capital spending are strong ways in which the new government is delivering for Rochester and Strood.

04 Oct 2024

To ask the Secretary of State for Transport, whether the Buses Bill would make local authority trade companies eligible to bid for bus franchises.

Lauren was delighted to visit Celessence Technologies last month to find out more about this globally successful business exporting worldwide from its base on the Medway City Estate. Joint CEOs Shibani Mohindra and Suzanne Powell and Business Development Manager Lee Robinson explained Celessence’s trademark microencapsulation technology, showed Lauren around the factory and introduced her to the rest of the team.
Celessence works with globally leading brands to enhance their textiles with natural scents, oils, and even anti-microbial properties. Celessence’s microcapsules once applied to textiles break down slowly over time, ensuring the benefits they bring to textiles are long-lasting.
Reflecting on the visit, Lauren said
“It was fascinating to learn more about this world-leading technology that is manufactured right here in Rochester and Strood and exported across the globe. Celessence are clearly an SME that punches above its weight led by two experienced and dedicated businesswomen. In my role as their MP, I’m looking to support them further in my work on skills and apprenticeships and learn more about how SMEs like Celessence can offer great manufacturing careers for young people.”

Labour has announced £5,023,000 to fix potholes in Medway as part of record £1.6 billion investment across England for 2025/26.
- The Government is also clamping down on disruptive street works
- Funding goes well beyond the Labour’s manifesto pledge, helping councils fix the equivalent of seven million potholes next year and saving drivers hundreds of pounds in repairs
- England’s roads have been plagued by potholes for too long, and the Government is investing to boost infrastructure as part of its Plan for Change.
Lauren Edwards, Labour Member of Parliament for Rochester and Strood, yesterday marked National Pothole Day by welcoming the Government’s plans for safer roads. The £1.6 billion investment to repair road networks in England is an increase of nearly 50% on local road maintenance funding from last year – going well beyond the Government’s manifesto pledge and is enough to fix the equivalent of over seven million extra potholes nationally in 2025/26.
Across England, local highways authorities will receive a 40% uplift in funding on average as the Government looks to rebuild Britain as part of its Plan for Change. Fixing our roads and filling potholes not only makes roads safer, but they also improve journey times and save drivers money from avoidable repairs. It comes as figures from the RAC show drivers in Rochester and Strood bear the cost of pothole damage to vehicles is around £500 on average a year, with more severe repairs costing considerably more. According to the AA, fixing potholes is a priority for 96 per cent of drivers.
This Labour Government is delivering its Plan for Change with investment and reform to deliver growth, improving living standards in Rochester and Strood and across the country by putting more money in people’s pockets and rebuilding Britain.
Lauren commented on the increased funding: “I am delighted that this Labour Government is doing things differently and taking swift action to fix our roads. Drivers have been plagued by potholes for too long, after 14 long years of Tory neglect. Under the Conservatives the situation spiralled out of control, with pothole damage costing drivers almost £500 million.”
”The impact of this funding will be seen by residents, with journeys across Rochester and Strood made safer, quicker and cheaper for drivers. This announcement goes well beyond the promises we made in our manifesto at the last election and shows that we’re serious about our Plan for Change.

Lauren Edwards recently visited the Cathedral Pie House on Eastgate, lending her support to the campaign for Traditional Speciality Guaranteed (TSG) recognition of Pie’n’Mash under the UK Government’s Protected Food Status scheme.
The visit also marked the celebration of the popular shop’s seventh birthday, opened by former boxer George Jupp.
The campaign seeks TSG certification, which guarantees the authenticity of traditional dishes. Cathedral Pie wants to preserve and celebrate the iconic dish of Cockney culture and put it on the map alongside other recognized British staples, such as Cornish pasties and Wensleydale Cheese.
Traditional Pie’n’Mash consists of a meat pie served with mashed potatoes, and parsley sauce called ‘liquor’. It has a heritage dating back to the 1840s and remains a staple of Cockney cuisine enjoyed by the ‘Cockney diaspora’ across South-East England.
Lauren emphasised the significance of preserving the heritage of traditional British foods.
“Pie’n’Mash is more than a meal; it’s a proud symbol of Cockney culture and tradition. Recognition through Protected Food Status will not only safeguard its authenticity but also ensure for future generations can experience the true taste of this British classic.
I was pleased to taste for myself the delicious Pie’n’Mash served by George to residents and tourists alike on Rochester High Street and recommend a visit. I’m strongly backing this campaign which will properly recognise the culinary heritage of this fantastic food eaten for centuries in the UK.”
George Jupp, owner of the Cathedral Pie House, stressed the importance of the recognition. “In other countries, unique foods are celebrated as essential part of their culture. Pie’n’Mash deserves the same respect. This isn’t just about tradition. It’s about celebrating a confident future for our favourite food”

In the Budget debate, Rochester and Strood MP Lauren Edwards welcomed the government’s investment in public services, including an additional £22.6bn for the NHS over the next two years. Despite the challenging financial inheritance from the last government, she was pleased to see a Labour government turn the page on decline with a budget that puts working people first and begins to repair our public services.
Informed by Lord Darzi’s assessment of the state of the NHS, the budget lays the foundation to take the NHS from the analogue to digital, from hospital to community-led care and from treating sickness to a renewed focus on prevention and promoting good health.
She also called for an elective care centre in Chatham High Street in her constituency, requesting further conversations with the Health Secretary having written to him with this proposal shortly after being elected.
As well as freeing up space at Medway Maritime hospital and helping to tackle long waiting lists, this would bring back into use a large building which has stood empty for several years, boosting footfall in the town centre and supporting regeneration efforts.
Lauren commented:
“This Labour government has put working people first in a budget which fixes the foundations of our economy and rebuilds our public services. We are providing record levels of investment in the National Health Service which will be targeted at slashing waiting lists and making it easier to access the care you need”.
“I took the opportunity to highlight the fantastic opportunity we have to open a new Elective Care Centre in the old Debenhams building in Chatham High Street. This investment would provide better access to a range of treatments and reduce waiting lists and current pressures on Medway Maritime Hospital”.
“I will continue to press the Health Secretary to support this proposal so that we can both improve health services for residents and support our town centres”.

Lauren today welcomed the announcement by the Chancellor Rachel Reeves that the government will approve the Lower Thames Crossing project, to be funded by the private sector.
This is a decision that is many years overdue and will help to both relieve congestion in the area and remove one of the key barriers to growth in our region.
Commenting on this long awaited greenlight for the project, she said:
‘I’ll be focused on making sure the impact on our local roads is managed appropriately and that residents and businesses in Rochester and Strood see the significant benefits the crossing offers.
Nearly two hundred businesses in Medway are already registered in the supply chain for the Lower Thames Crossing, so there is a huge opportunity for skilled jobs, local economic growth, and tourism’.

Lauren recently met Asda and Parentkind in Parliament to celebrate the success of Cashpot for Schools. This raised nearly £5.8m for more than 22,000 schools across the UK last year – including £13,691 shared between 33 primary schools across Rochester and Strood.
Lauren heard more about the scheme, the first of its kind, and was briefed on the work of Parentkind, Asda’s Community Champions, and the Asda Foundation. She also took the opportunity to meet with senior staff from ASDA to discuss their apprenticeships programme and how the government could make changes to improve completion rates and encourage more businesses to invest in their staff.
Speaking about the drop-in, Lauren said:
“With a large ASDA store in Strood and two smaller convenience stores in my constituency, I was pleased to attend the event to thank ASDA staff on behalf of our schools and celebrate the success of Cashpot for Schools. It’s great that over £13,000 has gone to local schools to invest in projects and support our young people. Further funding rounds will open soon, and I encourage even more schools to put in bids for 2025!
“It was also helpful to hear that ASDA has millions of pounds that it can’t use to train staff because of the rigidity of the current apprenticeship system. As Co-Chair of the All Party Parliamentary Group on Skills, Careers and Employment, I’ll be pushing to make sure Labour’s overhaul of apprenticeships in this country makes them simpler, more flexible and led by employers, so that this money can be used to invest in the workforce.”

I am proud to have been elected as your Member of Parliament for Rochester and Strood in July 2024. There is so much potential in our local communities, and I am working hard to unlock this and make sure our interests are represented in Westminster.
I moved to Rochester with my family in 2016 and am delighted to represent the diverse community that I call home.
Prior to being elected as the MP for Rochester and Strood in July 2024, I was the Cabinet Member responsible for Economic and Social Regeneration and Inward Investment on Medway Council from May 2023, and a Rochester East ward councillor from December 2021.
In my Medway Council Cabinet role, I sat on a number of regional external bodies focused on economic growth and skills, such as the South East Local Enterprise Partnership, the Kent and Medway Economic Partnership, the Kent and Medway Employment Taskforce, and the Kent and Medway Business Fund.
My professional background is as a financial regulator at the Bank of England, where I made sure that financial companies followed the rules put in place after the 2008 Financial Crisis. Prior to that, I worked as the lead postal researcher at the Communication Workers Union, focused on pay negotiations with Royal Mail and the Post Office. I also worked for a number of Labour MPs in Parliament.
I have over a decade of experience as an elected trade union representative.
I was born in Altona in Australia and came to the UK in 2005 to undertake a Master’s degree at the London School of Economics and Political Science.

I will be taking part in The Great Tommy Sleep Out later this month – a charity fundraising programme to raise awareness and money for our homeless veterans.
It’s not enough to simply show gratitude for the amazing work out veterans do for the UK, we must provide practical support. Their sacrifices strengthen our nation and keep us safe. But too many veterans find themselves in vulnerable situations, facing challenges such as homelessness, unemployment, and difficulty accessing the help they need. With an estimated 6,000 veterans in the UK lacking a permanent home, the reality is both stark and unacceptable.
In March 2025, thousands of people across the country will take part in this remarkable campaign. Participants will spend a night outdoors, an experience that reflects some of the hardships that our homeless veterans endure daily. The event is organized by the Royal British Legion Industries (RBLI), who provide dedicated support for our armed forces.
For me, taking part in this sleep-out is a way of supporting those who have faced life-changing challenges after serving our nation. I know our local community does a lot to help veterans navigate the complexities of returning to civilian life. However, there remains a significant gap between the support offered and the actual needs of many veterans. It is our responsibility to bridge this gap.
I am proud to that our Labour government is treating these issues with the seriousness they deserve, with over £4m being allocated to help end veteran homelessness. We have continued to champion the rights and well-being of our armed forces, advocating for measures to ensure that no veteran is left behind. From government commitments to provide secure housing solutions, to initiatives that promote better access to mental health services, Labour’s proactive approach is making a tangible difference.
The Great Tommy Sleep Out is an opportunity to highlight the message that every veteran deserves to be supported with dignity and respect. I encourage everyone to learn more about the issues facing our veterans and to get involved in any way they can – whether that means donating, volunteering, or simply raising awareness.
If you would like to donate to my sleep out you can do so at the following link. https://www.justgiving.com/page/lauren-edwards-mp?utm_medium=FR&utm_source=CL
Find out more about the Sleep Out here: https://rbli.co.uk/rbli-events/the-great-tommy-sleep-out/

Lauren has welcomed the government announcement to buy back over 36,000 military homes following yet another failed Conservative privatisation. This includes 317 homes in the Rochester and Strood constituency.
This plan to fix military housing is a major deal to bring the Armed Forces housing estate back into public ownership with billions of pounds being saved by the deal over the next decade, delivering savings for taxpayers and enabling additional investment into homes for military families.
The landmark move reverses a sale undertaken by the then Government in 1996, which meant billions of pounds has been spent renting back military homes that they shouldn’t have sold in the first place. Across the country, thousands of forces’ families are living with damp, mould and leaks after more than a decade of underinvestment in maintenance and repairs of these ageing homes.
Lauren commented:
“I am delighted that the government has acted in the interests of both military families in Rochester and Strood and the taxpayer to secure this deal.
“Military families, like those in our close-knit Brompton community, deserve high standards of accommodation and by taking back ownership we can ensure that they are warm, safe and good quality.
“Taking back control of the military housing estate also makes sense for the taxpayer – doing so will save the £230 million a year in rent or £600,000 per day.”

I welcome the publication of the Care Quality Commission (CQC) report on Medway Maritime Hospital, which highlights serious concerns about patient safety and the quality of care.
While urgent improvements are needed, I want to recognise the dedicated clinicians and staff who work under immense pressure, serving one of the largest catchment areas in the Southeast. High demand has put significant strain on services, and these challenges must be properly addressed.
The CQC has issued a Warning Notice requiring urgent and emergency care services to improve after finding multiple regulatory breaches. I welcome assurances from Medway NHS Foundation Trust that action is being taken, but these changes must happen swiftly.
I have also spoken with Paul Bentley, CEO of the Kent and Medway Integrated Care Board (ICB), about wider pressures on local NHS services, and I will continue working with healthcare leaders and ministers to drive improvements. I also welcome the Labour government’s additional £20bn NHS investment, which will support much-needed improvements.
Alongside this, I will keep pushing for investment in a new Elective Care Centre in Chatham to ease pressure on Medway Maritime, improve patient care, and support town centre regeneration.
Residents rightly expect safe, high-quality healthcare within Rochester and Strood and across Medway.

Please note that due to strict Parliamentary protocol, I am only able to make enquiries on behalf of my own constituents.
As your MP I can help with a variety of issues and concerns.
Keeping the issue private,
I can write to the relevant department, official, or Minister or make a personal appointment to discuss the issue. This can often go a long way to providing a solution to your issue.
I can also help to make the issue public by raising it in the House of Commons, where it will be officially recorded, and could potentially come to the attention of the press and public.
Outside Parliament, you can request that I speak at an event concerning your issue, pledge my support to a campaign or write to the local media on your behalf.
Time
Location
I hold regular advice surgeries. These are by appointment only and are usually reserved for complex cases. In most cases an appointment may not required, as it is usually quicker to get in touch with my team of dedicated caseworkers who will be able to help you.
My team in Rochester and Strood can often help without you having to attend an advice surgery. Contact my constituency office via one of the ways listed below and a member of the team will get in touch.
In most cases an appointment is not required, and it is usually quicker to get in touch so we can start work right away.
Email address
Phone Number
I welcome opportunities to meet with local groups, organisations and businesses throughout Rochester and Strood.
Please consider inviting me to your meeting or event, but understand that it will not always be possible, due to my parliamentary and other commitments.
